title: Chelsea winger Tyrique George agrees move to Premier League rivals
body_text:
Tyrique George is set to move to Everton on loan after the Toffees agreed a deal with Chelsea for the winger.
The 19-year-old has been linked with a number of clubs over the last year after emerging as one of the brightest prospects at Chelsea but unable to break into the first team on a regular basis.
George had agreed a permanent move to Fulham in the summer transfer window last year, but the deal fell apart on deadline day.
The teenager is now set for a move to Merseyside, with The Athletic reporting that the clubs have reached an agreement in principle.
The deal will see George move on loan for the rest of the season, with Everton having an option to buy him in the summer.
The agreement will be a boost for the Toffees, after another loan signing, Jack Grealish, has suffered a possibly season-ending injury.
The England international, on loan from Manchester City, is dealing with a stress fracture in his foot and may not play for Everton again.

Despite a solid season, which sees David Moyes’ side sit ninth in the Premier League, goals have proved difficult to come by.
After a 1-1 draw at Brighton on Saturday, Everton have scored just 26 goals in 24 league games, fewer than the likes of Leeds United in 16th and West Ham in 18th.
More Trending
George has just one Premier League goal to his name in his short career so far, but has shown that he can find the back of the net in other competitions this season.
The teenager has scored twice in three Carabao Cup appearances this campaign and also netted in the Champions League when the Blues thrashed Ajax 5-1 in October.
Everton boss Moyes said on Friday that any incomings were looking unlikely, telling a press conference ahead of the trip to Brighton: ‘We’re certainly looking. It’s not like we’re shying away from it. I would say it’s probably less likely than likely.’
However, it looks like the Toffees have got a deal done ahead of going to Fulham in their next outing on Saturday afternoon.
